Name: 77 Days in September: A Novel of Survival, Dedication, and Love (The Kyle Tait Series) (Volume 1)

ReviewList.Text: This book was recommended to me.  I was somewhat skeptical as I began reading, but was quickly drawn in.  It has all the elements of an excellent novel.  The characters are well defined, believable and easy to relate to.  The plot, however fictitious, is grounded in reality and calls attention to a truly catastrophic, yet largely ignored threat to international security.  The plot and pacing are first rate, as the story never dragged or failed to hold my interest.  More importantly, it made me *care* about the people and events as I read.  Ray Gorham has done an outstanding job in researching and writing this novel.

I think we have talent here.  From the Forward I was hooked. The idea of an EMP never crossed my mind and it made the story line believable.  What better way to hold your interest than to have two people deeply attached to each other trying desperately to get back together after a major event changes all the circumstances of their separation.  All the subplots fit tightly especially Doug. The experiences that Kyle had as he tried to get back to Montana were very real.  There were no slow spots in the storyline.  A very good summer read.

I'm dipping my toes into the waters of reviewing on Amazon, largely because of the courteous plea to do so by the author in a note at the end of the book. I have been on a post-apocalyptic reading jag for a while now, and this novel is in the middle of the pack for me. It moves right along, contains only a few errors (wretch when author means retch, as in to dry heave, strait when the author means straight, as in straight hair.) Having read more than a few novels which clearly hadn't been edited, read aloud by the author, or even run through a spell-checker, I appreciate what I used to take for granted in a novel - that I wouldn't be bumped out of it constantly by blatant errors in spelling, punctuation, formatting, etc. There are several pretty decent plain language explanations of how an EMP creates the destruction that it does, which are helpful to anybody who doesn't understand it to begin with. SPOILER ALERT:I will say that I was never in any real doubt that Kyle would make it home. It would have been a nice twist if he had frozen to death and Rose had found his journal and some months or years later it had gotten to Jenn. Not nice in the sense that it would have been a nice outcome for the character, but nice in the sense that the reader's expectations have been upended, and now they really need to pay attention because they don't know what's coming next. But a tidy little novel, a happy ending, nice motivation to prepare for the unexpected if you haven't yet begun to do so. For me, the best post-EMP novel remains One Second After. But this novel is worth the $3.99 Kindle price if you enjoy these types of stories. I would encourage the author to make his next novel more complex, and include more of the challenges any community would face after an EMP event. He alluded to the better prepared people in Deer Creek not participating in the council, leaving people in need with not much to give to try to figure things out. This really could have been a source for a lot of juicy conflict. Does the council send emissaries to ask these better-prepared people for help? What kind of reception do they receive? What is the response, the rationale for either helping or not? I'm giving this novel three stars; I'd give One Second After four stars, and save five stars for Cormac McCarthy's The Road.
This is a great idea looking for a good writer. This book isn't it.  Reading it on a Kindle made me long for an EMP to wipe out technology.

Excellent read. I sat down to read a couple of chapters and ended up sitting up all night and part of the next day, reading non-stop. The characters and their storylines were compelling; you wanted to find out what  was going to happen. Definitely a scarey idea if a EMP event were to take place in space over the continental US and the resulting damage to North American electrical and computer systems.

my favorite past time is reading. I was recommended this book from a friend, so I read the description and gave it try. I was skeptical at first because most books I read are Thrillers or love stories. I could not put this book down. I loved the Character and just felt myself following him in his Journey. The Author did a great job on this book and I will add him to my list of authors to watch out for more books.

A bit predictable, but I enjoy this type of book. I did want the main character to be more action oriented, but the reality his situation was probably portrayed accurately. I you like the EMP scenario, I would recommend this book along with, Lights OUt and One Second After.

This book gets one star for only wasting one day of my life, not a few days like Lights Out did.  I enjoy this genre but it has been nearly impossible to find anything that is interesting.  I can suspend disbelief, however, I need to be a little entertained.  Some reviewers thought this would be a good teen reading book. I think not because half of the book (that takes place in Montana) revolves around the perverted Sheriff trying to rape one of the main characters.  I don't have a problem with reviewers saying this author has right wing leanings.  I think most of these survival stories are like that and it doesn't bother me as a total "lefty".  I suppose all liberal humans would just die on the first day of an EMP attack. I do wonder though if all "right wing types" think women are so useless except for sex. This was a silly book, a painfully strange way of going about writing a love story.  After reading this book and Lights Out, I feel I should amend my review of The Pulse to a higher rating.  Of course, One Second After being the best.  Can't wait for a woman to write a book on this subject to see if it is possible that women are not helpless stepford wives, weaklings or sex objects.  Yikes, please skip this book.

I am an avid reader, especially of the post-apocalyptic sort. There have been so many disappointing books out there that I was scared to try one more. This is the book that turned me around. It is a fairly believable story. The characters have their worlds with their appropriate personalities. I was also quite please that this book didn't linger on for pages and pages about technical details. Many books will cover half to one and a half pages entirely on the type of knife they bought. Not here. I bought this book yesterday afternoon and stayed up until four in the morning to finish it. I give this book four stars. While this book could have been a bit better, not everyone can be the best author around. The only burden this book left me with was that it is NOT available in print. Reading from my cell phone all night wasn't the greatest.

This book was recomended to me by a friend. As i had not read anything by the author prieviously, i was not sure what to expect. Once started i found the story well written, exciting and hard to stop. The plot, once recognized, is a bit scary, as it could be history some day soon. quite well researched and very believable. It is always fun to read something with the story set in familiar territory. I am a fan of this style of writing and will add the author to my need to read list.

I always look at reviews before purchasing books, but I try not to read them too carefully since they often contain spoilers. I never bother with writing reviews, but I feel I must on this book to save others a few bucks and a couple of hours of their lives that they'll never be able to get back.This was an interesting idea, but it was executed so poorly. There was so much "telling" in this story and so little action. Many of the conversations are so artificial sounding, and sometimes over-the-top dramatic, I just found myself constantly rolling my eyes. I finally just started skimming the pages. A friend of mine recommended this book to me, and she really liked it, so I know that some of these glowing reviews are probably legit. But if you care about how well a story is written, then this is not the story for you.

For "futurists" like me, this book is a worthwhile read.  We don't worry enough about the dangers in our electronic world.  Ray Gorham has written an important novel that should awaken us to the catatrophic possibilities that we should recognize and prepare for. A well-written narrative of one family's experience, it is a fast read, slowed at the beginning by the Tom Clancy-type technical explanations necessary as a base for the story. it grips the reader in every chapter. Reminiscent of THE ROAD, but more down-to-earth, 77 DAYS takes us into an authentic story of a grim future. Gorham is a proficient writer and I look forward to his next novel.  Orin Parker

I've read other great books about an EMP attack (lights out and one second after are both excellent) but unlike those books which focus on survival by setting up a community or growing food, etc... this book focuses on one man's journey from Texas To Montana after an EMP attack.  It is a completely different kind of book but I felt it was an amazing portrayal.  One thing that was VERY refreshing about this was that that main charachter wasn't a survival expert, a military trained man, nor was he a "regular" guy that just happened to be a sharp shooter with tons of guns.  No, this is an average guy.  A guy that gets his ass kicked and makes mistakes.  The book is short and so a lot is still left up to imagination, but I think it was more realistic than a lot of other books because it focused mostly on one person and not on how a community suddenly comes together and fights off gangs and learns to farm, etc...  Great book.

I found this story slow and hard to get excited about.  I wanted more technical detail and intriguing character interactions.  I was particularly disappointed with the ending. It felt like the author said "well, it's time to wrap it up..." and just tied up all the loose ends in a few pages.

I could not finish this poorly written book. The dialog between the characters was not only boring, it was unrealistic. The main character's kindergarten aged son had conversations with his mother that were not at all what you would expect of a child at this age which proved to be just another waste of words in this book. Then there were all of the grammatical errors throughout the portion of the book that I read that led me to believe that this book was rushed to electronic print without a thorough edit. I would pass on this read.

Wow. This was one of the best books I've read in a long time. It was hard to stop reading, and the characters were real and engaging.  I could hardly wait to see what would happen to Kyle next, and each obstacle he encountered made me care about him more and more. The story reminded me of all I have, and that family relationships matter more than anything. It showed the spectrum of the human spirit-from depravity and selfishness to sacrifice and triumph. It was a fantastic read and would make a truly remarkable movie!

I absolutely loved this book. I thought the relationships were very real and the book "brought me into the story". I did not anticipate or expect what would happen. It definitely kept me wanting more. The writing was detailed and I had a good mental image of everything as it was happening. I tend to read books by authors. If I find one book I love, I will read every book that author has written and the same goes here. I would definitely look for another book by this author. I could also see this book as a movie. Very interesting and enlightening subject. The ending was beautiful. GREAT book.

I finished this book only because I paid for it. I hate to write a negative review but seeing as I paid based on so many positive reviews, it only seemed fair. My slog through this book was much like Kyle's walk. Exhausting, staggering and tortured. Seriously, how can there be this many positive reviews? I got into this genre by accident reading "Breakers". Loved THAT book. This one had no character development, was written like a highschooler would write, typos and very "vanilla" which in itself is acceptable if the writing is tolerable. Skip this one!

For most of us who enjoy the post apocalyptic genre of fiction we have grown accustomed to enduring subpar writing. Enjoyably, this work is written fairly well. The author has taken the trouble to edit his work avoiding the all to common misspellings which seem to plague so many ebooks. I do have a few criticism which did annoy me while reading. Firstly, the main character is presented as hypersensitive and somewhat effeminate in many circumstances. Mostly, it is an inconsistent trait which seems in place because the author is trying to make a statement about the good husband, good father and good human. I don't begrudge him this as out of place elements are typical when authors try to make statements. In the same vein, the protagonist is presented as a rational, reasonable and of at least average intelligence, yet time and time again he seems to turn his brain off and do something so stupid that I ended up with my face in my palm. Furthermore, he seems to lack any ability to learn from his mistakes as he does the same thing over again which had just nearly cost him his life (which he inexplicably and miraculously escapes). This is an all to common lazy element for writers to introduce the next conflict/action sequence. It really is not needed in a world gone to hell where even if someone does everything right, circumstance beyond their control can still bite them in the posterior. It would have been more palatable if the character had been introduced as suffering from schizophrenia or multiple personality disorder as this would at least explain the discordant behaviour. This is equally applicable to the female lead in dealing or rather not dealing with the possible rape and threat to her children. The author also seems to have at least a subconscious dislike of firearms (at a minimum he dislikes keeping track of them or explaining what happend to what would be a most precious possession). There are points in the story where firearms are not used, even if a bluff, which would avoid a conflict. At other points in the story a gun is used stupidly and dangerously. Thankfully, anyone with even a touch of critical thinking ability will spot that the characters idiocy is to blame for trouble rather than a firearm. Lastly, the author seems to have grown tired of telling his tale and just drops it at the end. The protaganist makes it to the stateline, hop, skip and a jump later he is home, the end. To wrap up, if you are like me and enjoy this genre you will be able to overlook any of my perceived flaws in the writing and still enjoy the read. (please excuse any of my spelling or grammatical errors as I did not edit this)

I'm so glad that somebody brought the problem of the EMP attack up. Maybe this book will make people consider that we, as Americans, are just as vulnerable as anyone else on this globe if another government really wants to attack us. We go around so cock-sure that our technological advances and our government so efficient that we are fail safe. Not so. And this storyline about the travails of one middle class family, with no pre-planning for the worst, just attempting to stay alive, as unharmed as possible while attempting to re-gather into their family group is seriously riveting. Good read!

Finally a really really good read without the  F word. Once upon a time a good read was exactly that now it doesn't get published without dripping in smut. A fantastic story page after page. I would love to read a sequel from another point of view.
Just finished the book and really enjoyed it.  Reminded me somewhat of Blake Crouch's "Run.". Fast paced and realistic, few editing errors.  Write another one please!

If you like "end of the world" type stuff, this book is for you. Especially at the Kindle price. A well written, SCARY to even think about premise.  Good story, characters sometimes did stupid stuff (sort of like when you are yelling at the TV "don't go into the dark scary basement", sort of stuff) but overall well written and believable.

This novel is sooooooo bad! I got over the completely useless methods the main character uses to journey home, but what really made me dislike this  was the complete nonsense of his encounters with any and all villains. He makes the same stupid mistakes over and over yet doesn't die. Incredible! Three quarters of the way though, I just wanted him to die and save us both more un-needed pain. OK, Kyle has started crying again, I simply can't imagine anyone wanting a effeminate, scared lead-man for their post disaster novel. I'm done.

The idea was interesting, the story boring and predictable. The author has many preconceived notions that come out in his writing, that are just not informative or well researched. There is just no depth to the book at all.

I found this book to be very well written, from a storytelling perspective and from a technical one.  I find it annoying when I continuously come across misspelled or misused words in very obvious use that go undetected by either the author or the publisher prior to going to print.  That didn't happen here - I believe I found one misspelling. The storyline never dragged during the fleshing out of the plot and the building of the characters.  Instead, the story built in a continuously progressive manner and maintained my interest without the use of fantastic and unusual events giving the reader the feeling that everything described could have actually happened and I appreciated that very much.  As a hardcore survivalist, the reason I read this material is to envision the possible unfolding of disastrous situations and how to mentally prepare for certain possibilities and this story actually gave me all of that in a very entertaining form.  I was able to consider the things the character did and what I would have done in his place at each step along the story way. I was also able to develop variations on the situations that develop and consider what I would do in those situations as well.  The story was very thought provoking and the author's ability to describe the events with expansive detail was well noted and appreciated.  I also appreciated his sense of moral values with regard to situations that arose and his sensitive approach to the explanations made for the choices his character made when having to deal with a variety of moral issues.

Actually, my husband bought this book for me for Christmas, so this is his account I'm using to submit my review.  I love survival stories.  I've read many books like this, and even had the opportunity to edit one for a popular author in this arena.  Mr. Gorham did a marvelous job writing this book and using descriptive language to help the reader form a picture of the scenario in his or her mind.  I am impressed that he stayed away from using the hard core survivalist stereotype: the "man who thought ahead of everything and has all the answers, including a stock of military clothing for when the SHTF".  I was also impressed that the book started with an actual scenario from a 1962 nuclear test and related the actual effects of an EMP.  I have seen survival blogs wrestle with discussions about what will actually work or fail electronically and for the first time, I felt I had a clear picture of what to expect post-EMP.  I was surprised to learn that in 1962, some auto ignitions failed after that nuclear test was conducted over 900 miles away at an altitude of about 250 miles up. BRAVO!  A real life example with facts, not speculation.  Great descriptions of human behavior!  I saw an earlier comment about punctuation; who cares?  Can't wait to read your next book!  Congratulations, Mr. Gorham!

Thank you Mr Ray Gorham for making the characters in you book real. Thank you for making the hero, Kyle, a power company employee and not a former Green Beret, Seal, Marine Sniper or martial arts expert. I really enjoyed the way you showed both the best and worst in people in a believable way. I liked the way that his home town worked together without people having unrealistic hoards of survival gear and weapons. You showed how life could be difficult and depressing but also how much better neighbors we could become when we have to depend on each other. All in all I loved everything about this story. It was not so unbelievable like Lights Out (which I did enjoy a great deal) or so depressing like One Second After (well written but I felt empty after finishing it). A good balance of uncertainty and hope. I look forward to your next book.

My routine over the past few years has left little time for reading. Generally, I pick up a book and never finish it because I don't have the time or the book does not grab me long enough to make that time. When I began reading this book, I knew right away what a great find it was. I found myself staying up late into the night reading. I have not done this in ages. Thank you for writing such a great book. You had a grown man emotional throughout. As a veteran, I know how hard it is to be away from family. I encourage anyone who has not heard of this book to give it a read.

this was my first book of this genre, and because of this book it wasn't my last.  I am going to reread this book as I found it very thought provoking, And I still to this day think abou this book and it's been a while since I read it.  very good.

I normally enjoy this type of fiction and finished the book relatively quickly. Certain parts relating to the main character's journey and survival were interesting (especially the description of the snow storm), but overall it was not well written. The dialogue was stilted and the characters were one-dimensional. The main character's wife in particular was annoyingly helpless. I wouldn't have minded the obvious right-wing slant if it weren't so clunky heavy-handed. It wasn't unpleasant to read but you'll find yourself doing a lot of eye rolling.
Pun intended. Read some of the well written one-star reviews before you purchase this novel, I wish I did. "Apocalypse of boredom" by Moondonkey is a great review.

I was looking for a good read to fill my hunger for post-apocalyptic dystopian survival and ended up tearing up at work during my lunch hour, emotionally unprepared for what I was reading. The story was excellent and I couldn't put it down. I got angry at the characters and thought that I would have handled situations differently, but I really cared about them and constantly related to how I and/or my wife would respond to the scenarios. A couple times I thought the book might fall too deep into dark/nihilistic territory only to be given relief at the very last second, gasping for air as I thought I might drown in the tension. Being young in my marriage and having a little one now, I could relate with the main character in ways a few years ago I would have never imagined. I feel that the author maintained an excellent balance between the realistic desperation of a society that had fallen apart with a light at the end of the tunnel that says that even in the darkest of hours, there is always hope, and always reason to live. Without being preachy, the author conveys a deep sense of love and faith in a manner that anyone of good-will can feel good about. For me as a deeply flawed but devout Catholic and family man, I felt emboldened to be a better father, husband, and son, and maybe prepare a little more for an emergency, too.

I teach Alas, Babylon every year to my freshman and they always want to know if anything like it could happen today. I feel this book really would appeal to them. I am going to recommend this to my students who finish Alas, Babylon early. I think they would all enjoy it as much as I did.  I sure hope nothing like this ever happens.

I have been reading alot of end-of-civilization books lately, and this one was one of the most riveting.  The author draws you in to the main character, and you both empathize with him and simply become him.  Heartily recommend this!

The book was a good read, moved quickly and character development was adequate.  Plot was alittle jerky at times with indepth plot structure at times but less at others.  Overall though for a indie author it was very good.  As another Montanan who flys back and forth to Texas this just gives me something else to worry about on the flight!!!  Good book would recommend to all my friends and family.

I am a sucker for disaster books and movies and this book hooked me right away. It was hard to put down, I finished it in 2 days. The characters were likeable and believable. I highly recommend it and plan on looking for more from this author.

Outstanding read from a fan of the PA genre.  There were times when I felt I was walking right beside Kyle, experiencing his struggles.  As a father of 3 children, the range of emotions that the main character felt resonated well with me.  Just an all-around great read.... I could not put it down.

Excellent book. I have read "One second after" which is a new York times best seller written by a man who is an authority on the subject. I loved that book and this book was just as good if not better. If this book had the publicity that "One second after" had, then I believe this also would be a best seller. Buy it you will love it.
Excellent read in the tradition One Second After. While not heavy on technical aspects like some Post-Apocalyptic books, the characters were very believable, and I can't wait to see what comes after.

This book is AMAZING!!!  I absolutely loved it!  It is very well written, and very believable.  It caught my interest right from the start and kept it through out the entire thing.  It was very thought provoking and emotional for me.  I loved the characters; they were easy to relate to.  I could NOT stop reading!!! This is the kind of book that I would love to read again!!!  I will definitely be looking for more to read from this author!  Well done!

I have read many post-apocalyptic novels and in most the main character is a former special forces genius or a tremendously well armed doomsday prepper that makes the story seem so fake. Ray has hit upon the perfect combination of events and characters that makes most readers truly believe that they could be Kyle, me included. I just could not put this book down. I will be purchasing the next installment in the Kyle Tait story as soon as I finish this review. Ray, keep up the great work and I don't think you will be an independent author much longer if that is your goal. I have already recommended this book to several friends. I will definitely be looking for more of your work. Great job!

Just a great, cant put it down, read! Thank you Ray Gorham! Really enjoyed this book. If the United States is gonna' be defeated by a nuclear bomb, this is how its going to happen, in my opinion. Would be easy to do by any country that has access to an ICBM. Scary stuff and well written. Don't know if and what other books Ray has written, but I am searching as soon as I post this review! Thanks again, Ray!

I read a lot of books and if you check out my reviews you will see that this is only the second time I have given 5 stars.  I share the authors real concerns about and EMP scenario and enjoy this survival genre, but usually find that even well known authors are just enjoyable reads, not well written novels.  This was very well edited and contained none of the grammar, spelling or continuity errors that are so common in online books.  There are well developed characters that I grew to care about.  I definitely recommend this book to anyone who likes survival or adventure novels or even triumph of the human spirit stories.  I was impressed and will definitely read the next book by this author.

This book is definitely hard to put down long enough to EAT!!  I'm a slow reader, until I get a book this well written and engaging.  This author should be considered one of the best. I work with emergency preparedness and have read much on EMPs and found this book to contain much that is accurate (though frankly, according to my scientist friends who do this work,  many cars do make it- running after the testing in EMP simulations).  The characters were real, you could relate to them and feel all the emotions encountered in the book.  One thing I particularly like, that few authors can do, is Ray Gorham is able to have such an engaging book WITHOUT any colorful language, obviously a rare skill, since so many authors can't seem to do that.  I often put down books in the early chapters no matter the plot, fed up with continuous foul language. Not here.  Important for my family, though we are a prepared family, this book has caused us to modify some of our own preparations for disasters. I have recommended it to others.
This story had me from page one to the end .. I'm glad book 2 was available, because I'm starting it next.  Good Job Ray Gorham!

This is the second novel I've read revolving around the very real threat of a EMP attack and tho a novel it is full of information we need to give serious thought to. That aside it's a great read. I could not put this down as each page gripped your emotions as the fears, courage and strength of the main character were believable and so real. The author never strayed from his story and not once did I think or wonder why on earth Kyle made the hard decisions he was forced to make as he struggled onward. Wonderful story by a very talented new author!  Hope the next in the series is ready because I certainly am anxious to continue the journey with these special characters.
Really enjoyed the book. Very thought provoking. Pity world governments dont think about their actions more. I look forward to the next book.

This is the third survival book that I have read. The other two bored me stiff, even though I learned something from reading them. This book has a nice story, while also giving one a glimpse into a possible future, thus helping the reader to consider preparation for survival. Stephen King is still my favorite author, but this book did not disappoint me.  -Fellow Montanan

I was not impressed with the writing. The story was okay, but the writing lacked logical thought. In one place, a person could not ride a bike across country, but they could do 15 miles in an afternoon. (as a biker, I would totally take a bike over this guys choice, no mater what the 'expert' said in the shop, but to then go on and have another person bike 15 miles just made no sense). When talking about the past, the timeline was incorrect and contradictory. In on sentence they started dating in high school, in another he had a relationship with someone else... I can suspend belief only so far... bending basic logic rules just makes me not like the book.

77 days in September is of the post apocalyptic genre and I found this to be an easy read and not too gruesome which may be a bit unrealistic but after reading so many of this type I found less gruesome to be OK.

Ray Gorham tells an inspiring story of devotion in this book. Aside from multiple typos ( I think mainly from the electronic versions only), this is a must read. Maybe he will continue the story????? Can't wait to see!!! Great job Mr Gorham. Please continue.

Don't bother with this one, read "One Second After" instead.  I'd read OSA and thought with good reviews this might be another interesting twist on the EMP story but it was orders of magnitude behind OSA.

I'm a big fan of post apocalyptic fiction, so i purchased this book after reading a few reviews and I'm glad i did! I've read alot of PA fiction from zombies to super viruses to ecological disasters but this is the first I've read about EMP and it really made for a very different story.  It's scary to really think about how much we rely on technology! The story was sometimes a little predictable but i still thoroughly enjoyed it, especially how i got to see two very different sides of the story and the very different challenges Kyle and Jennifer faced. A great read for any sci fi fan!

Weak cry baby main character.  In the end i really did not care what happened to him.  Main character seemed to be unwilling or afraid to fight for his life and regularly depened on the kindness of other to survive......not a fan
Amazon are you looking? This book needs to be in print! The reviews are amazing. Plus, look how much money you are losing.

Everyone should read this book.  I wish they would make it into a movie.  It totally motivated me to set up an extensive emergency supply closet stocked with everything these people didn't have.  I am sooooo ready if an EMP hits.  This will motivate you to get ready too.  Not only is it a "heads up people" book, but it is also a story about the good vs. evil inside of the human race and includes a love story so it's not a depressing read as some of the other emp books are.

This author surprised me. I knew he wasn't well-known and so my expectations weren't super-high. Of course, I sampled a bit before buying and was impressed enough to buy it. But it turned out to be a very, very good read - excellent, in fact. I then gave it to my wife and she loved it, too. I highly recommend it.

I read this book in about a day and a half. I've recently been into American disaster stories and  this one had a concept I hadn't heard of before... a terrifyingly possible concept. The writing was a little choppy and the dialogue made me cringe a few times but the overall story was well told and worth reading. But I think I'm going to go buy some seeds and MRE`s.
Interesting book. This book was both engaging, and made me aware of a potential danger. It inspired me to get some disaster preparedness supplies.

The concept for this book was very interesting and the book started off as a great attention getter although it slowed down in the middle  and I found myself basically skipping pages.  All and all a pretty good read,
Great concept, bad execution. Bought this on a kindle deal of the day, and it seems they put a lot of amateur writers on sale there. The dialogue was like something a middle schooler would write.

This is a solid read. So many times we have to choose a story by the "feeling" we get from the description or one or two reviews from total strangers. Lets face it...you just never know until you dive in. Well "Dive In" to this one! The story is believable and the characters really grab hold of you. Some you'll be pulling for and others routing against. I walked along with Kyle for a few thousand miles and loved every second. Take a chance on a new writer! Nice job Ray!!

I liked the premise of an EMP disaster. However the story left out all the possibilities the author mentioned as modes of transportation. Why in the world would a man WALK when he could ride a bike, steal an 'old' car (the ones that supposedly work in this scenario?) ride a horse, a wagon...even rollwer skate for cryin' out loud...still a rather entertaining yarn that held my interest for a few days...

This book ws so suspensful and intriguing . i didn't want to have to set it down to go to work and when i got home i couldn't wait to pick it up again . I'd like to find more books by this author on similar subjects . If you're looking for something a little diffrent this is the one to read .

Mister Gorham, let us pray that radical Islamics never discover "77 Days in September," and that your book becomes required reading for the Secretary of Defense, Congress, the Pentagon and the United States President. *No Spoilers* I agree with some previous reviewers that some of the dialog was completely unreal, and I also don't know if I buy into how desperate humankind became within a mere 77 days. But I understand the changes moved fast to keep the book from being called 277 days in September and hence being boring. The good news is, if you get past that, this book is a really fun, easy read. The author is a solid writer who, unlike other new writers, does not try to show off with overly flowery writing as though his best friend is his thesaurus. This novel is clear, concise, and gripping. I liked the characters and the scenes were perfectly described. The premise really made me consider how my family, neighborhood, etc would fare in such a situation. I recommend checking it out.

This book showed up in my Facebook ads and I was bored, so I checked it out.  After reading the Amazon-provided preview, I could tell that the book was written in a style that would keep my interest, so I bought it.  I read it and loved it so much that I emailed the author to thank him personally, and he even responded very courteously to my email, which surprised me.  I've read the other reviews for this book, both the top and the bottom.  I think the criticisms of the one-star reviews are unfair and vicious.  The book contains a few homonym slip-ups and stretches the rules of Oxford English (like a tendency to put apostrophes on plural nouns) but if you're going to get your panties in a bunch over a few misplaced words in a SELF-PUBLISHED, nearly 300-page novel, go get a job as an editor, SAT grader, or English teacher, and stop tearing apart the first efforts of a first-time author.  The book is written from a distinctly conservative worldview, though it's certainly not as onerous as it could be, but if you're a raging liberal, you probably won't enjoy it. Don't read it and then whine because someone wrote a book which reflects their own way of thinking.  The characters aren't phenomenally complicated or innovative, but not everyone has to have some sort of giant secret or second personality in order to be interesting.  The book is written from the perspective of the characters, so their choices or alternatives aren't always explained.  I think that makes it more real - that there are possibilities which the characters don't think about is in keeping with the desperate nature of the situations they are in.  They need to act, not sit around planning out all of their alternatives.  The story purposely focuses on the two main characters, Kyle and Jenn, instead of delving into the (admittedly interesting) side plots of the other survivors.  Perhaps future works could build on this? Kyle is a simple, honest man just trying to get home to his family.  He doesn't have the deviousness or viciousness of character necessary to be a killer, and he relies heavily on the kindness of strangers to survive.  Readers may interpret this as being a weakness, and it's true that things work out just a little *too* coincidentally well for him in some places, but at its heart this is not a survival story.  If I may quote the author's words, "My goal when starting to write was to tell a story about a couple overcoming immense challenges to stay together, and stay true to each other, the EMP aspect was just a way to put them in that situation. "  There you have it.  If you want good disaster literature, look somewhere else.  This is a fairly simple story of honor and dedication, characters with a refreshingly strong morality in today's "feel-good morality" and "every man for himself" society (both in the real and literature worlds).

Just finished Ray Gorham's "77 Days in September."  I have to say that this book grabbed my attention like few have in recent years. The factual research behind the highly technical topic brings vivid detail to the fictional scenario.  This is a very important subject as it is actually one of the easiest ways for our enemies to bring down our society if they had the means and money.  As a fellow author, my only regret is buying the Kindle version, as the printed copy would have given the author a more deserving royalty.  It a quick, enjoyable and instructive read...I would strongly recommend it!

This book however is an uplifting story about one man's triumph in the face of overwhelming odds to be reunited with his family.  I hope the author writes more tales like this.

Once I started reading I couldn't put it down. Ray has done a fantastic job creating believable situations and characters in this book, very glad I found it while searching through Amazon!  This was my first kindle download and I couldn't be happier.  A completely different view on an after-EMP event than "One Second After" but just as good of a read, and just as emotional.  Great book Ray, I will be letting friends know about it!

So the snow was coming down and I found a good read last weekend.  It took me awhile to find the logic of the book title until I read it.  I really enjoyed the book as I was able to relate to the characters, ideas and situations the author portrayed.  I enjoy books and movies that have a mission in mind based on good principles.  I saw symbolism that opened my eyes from my perspective of a Christian and the battles one has internally between good and evil.  It sure made interesting conversation at work about the possibility of an EMP detonating above the United States and if I'd be ready.  I got some good ideas from the characters in the book that were prepared and how their preparation was beneficial for others.  Don't get me wrong, I'm not one to scare myself into the extremes but got a real sense of how grateful I am to live in Montana, out in the country, living next to family enjoying the many freedoms I and my family have.  I've lived out of the country before and understand the lack of government, law enforcement and civility at times of crisis so I could relate somewhat to the situation or the lack of some basic necessities in that case.  I'd love to see this book into a screenplay because I enjoy action movies.  Maybe I'm a hopeless romantic in a way but glad the book ended the way it did.  Maybe the next book will end different but it was a good start to a series (hint hint).  Great read, thought provoking and inspiring!

After reading the forward to this book and then doing a little research of my own (prior to starting the book, but after reading the forward) I had a sinking feeling in my stomach that this was going to be an eye opening, scare the hell of me kind of book and Ray Gorham did not disappoint!  Yes, post apocalyptic stories full of zombies and other nasty creatures make for good reading, but there is nothing more frightening then the reality of what Kyle and his family endure. The fact that this book may very well become reality before I even finish writing this review should (and will) keep you awake at night, not from what may be under your bed or in your closet, rather the fact the someone, somewhere in the world is plotting to try this very thing!
This story is well-thought out and a gripping read. You actually care if Kyle gets home. The misuse of commas was quite distracting but the story is worth it.

This was a decent read, entertaining although a bit repetitive. However, to save some other readers some trouble many times throughout the book it leaned heavily right wing conservative with a strong dose here and there of Christian propaganda I just skipped over these moments and moved on. If you are a tea bagger this will be right up your alley, if not this will deter from a decent story that would have been just fine without it.

I found this book to be very entertaining and it kept my attention well. The subject matter was thought provoking and realistic. I had a hard time putting it down...so much so, that I had to rewarm my bathtub water twice one night. I will definately be recommending this book to my friends - wish it was on paper so I could recommend it for my bookclub.

I was disappointed but not surprised at the waste of time reading this turned out to be. Horrible prose, disingenuous plot, shallow characters and an atrocious editorial job made this book just another generic, rehashed thriller, with which the market is already saturated. At least Tom Clancy could spare the time to hire an editor, which Mr. Gorham evidently found not to be worth it. A waste of money.

Enjoyed the book from page one to the end. Few books have ever brought tears to my eyes as the end of this well written book. I encourage all readers who enjoy post apocalypse books to read this book. I am anxious to order the follow up book and read the continuation of Kyle and his family.

I just finished this book today and thoroughly enjoyed it. There were several scenes that were quite gripping and tense. There were several scenes where I thought the main characters were going to choose the less-than-moral choice, but was pleasantly surprised when they didn't. I'm not sure how realistic that was, but it made for a satisfying read. The explanation of an EMP and how it could occur seemed realistic and well-written. I'm giving it only four stars because I felt that more could've been done with the characters than there was. For example, the politician featured early on seems to be important, but we never really find out what happens to her, other than that she's waiting to die. I would like to have seen her play a more prominent role in the plot line. I think marauding gangs would've been a much bigger problem than was shown in this novel. Another novel that I read about EMP's, "One Second After", by William R. Forstchen, uses this and I think it is much more realistic than the few people that the main character in this novel runs across. I enjoyed the main characters' writing of the journal as he's traveling. I worried about it getting ruined in the snow, and would have liked to have seen more talked about on that. I also think the novel would have been better if it had been lengthened out by adding some more weather difficulties after the one storm. One big storm didn't seem like very much considering that winter was coming on. I would also like to have seen more about what happened to the son after he was injured; his struggle to survive and so on. Toward the end, it seemed like the author was tired of writing the book so he just wrapped everything up quickly. I was sad to see it end. I would like to read more by this author.

There's no way a book this bad should be so highly rated. The painfully one-dimensional characters, the gaping plot holes...I've purchased about 200 books from Amazon and this is the first time I feel like they should offer a refund.

OK, it's easier to criticize than to actually "enter the arena" and write the book but, because of the overwhelming number of 4 and 5 star ratings, I felt compelled to comment.  I am a big fan of the post-apocalypse genre and have read a number of the EMP based novels.  Unfortunately, this one is pretty weak.  Flat characters, stilted dialog with very unnatural conversation structure.  The character of Kyle is so illogical in his choices, I am surprised he survived more than a week.  As for Jenn, it appears that the author either has limited insight into the complexity and capabilities of women or purposely created this weak, stereotyped character because it was an easy, if somewhat obvious, way to create tension on both sides of the story line.  He would have been well served to have this book rough edited to help with that character's creation and development.  As others have noted. If you are searching for an EMP apocalypse novel, start with "One Secong After" or "Lights Out". Both of which have, to some degree, the same failings but redeem themselves with much deeper exploration of the societal impact of this kind of an event.  If, however, one doesn't particularly care by what mechanism the End of the World as We Know It comes about, my all time favorite is "Lucifer's Hammer" by Niven and Pournelle.

These apocalyptic novels are sometimes similar but something new can always be learned each time one is read. The information they contain may be helpful one day because civilization as we know it is a fragile state of being that can easily be shattered. The authors always agree on several things. Each individual or family is on its own. Organized government will not help anybody because the government will be one of the first things to fall apart. Government will take care of its own first, through secret facilities or through martial law. The journey that Kyle has taken in this book will be typical of those caught up in the events of a catastrophe, trust of fellow human beings slowly destroyed by animal behavior, the constant hunt for food, water and shelter, the need to kill to save yourself and your family from bandits and murderers. Kyle handles things well, except for the decision to pull a cart of supplies behind him for 1500 miles. He would have been much better served by a bicycle with a basket, which would have given him the ability to cover 50 miles a day in the flat lands and to coast down the long hills. He also had a thousand miles to think about the cold weather up north and gather some warm, waterproof clothing but ended up nearly freezing to death. All in all, this is a worthwhile book that could easily become reality for many of us.

Very good! Couldn't put it down. And most of all, I am so glad this book did not rely on foul language to develop it characters and tell its story.  It is very refreshing not having to weed through offensive language trying to focus on a story.  Congratulations Mr Gorham, you avoided that very "easy" (and shallow) path which so many other authors take.  Notwithstanding, there are plenty of intense encounters that play out very effectively.  In fact, this style shows a higher writing skill by relying to solid, , creative and descriptive language instead of cheap gutter speak.  I only wish this style was the rule instead of the exception.  But, enough of that...  The story is believable and flows well.  And, believe it or not, here is finally a "grid-down" story that does not have a biker gang in it!!  The story does not attempt to cover every possible failure from an EMP, but there is one glaring omission which is my one criticism... nuclear plants.  i.e. The safety systems in nuke plants rely on the grid to function. If the grid goes down, the plants will begin the process of failure soon after losing power.  It would have been interesting to incorporate such a nationwide event into the story.
For adventurers, outdoor lovers, and romantics this is a fabulous tale of courage, fortitude, loyalty and love list then regained.  Hard to put down once you start reading!

All I can say is, you have to read this book. It is a bit scary because of its real possibility of actually happening. But even with this uneasy feeling one gets while reading it (due to fear of this COULD happen), one also begins to really root for the main characters. The main character Kyle Trait, got stuck in Texas while trying to fly home to his family in Montana. When the attack occurs, he almost dies when his plane almost crashes but amazingly does not. From that point on, the roller coaster ride begins.  He goes through a lot to get home to his family. He has to walk and along the way is confronted by both the best and worst of mankind. As in real life, the best of man helps overcome evil and helps Kyle along the way. The story also talks about how the attack has affected his family back home and their struggling. During several scenes, I actually almost started crying and cheering (inwardly of course) any time Kyle would overcome a seeming insurmountable obstacle. I don't  want to give too much away, but just say if you want a good strong story line, you need to read this book. It is the first of a series, and I want to read the others.
The basic idea for the story was good.  The writing was terrible, the character development was non-existant, and the dialogue was laughable at best.

Wish i could put words together in a way that would impress the average mama, like me, to soak in the message of this timely, well thought out and exceptionally important book. THEN to do the unexpected, at least for this non-prepping but concerned grandma. You see, we are many things to many people, many who will hopefully watch, listen AND then maybe do something differently than before. Ray Gorham is a gental, yet firm force to crack open the reluctant shell of those of us who would like to continue our view of a life with no major changes. As with most of us peering through our rose coloured glasses, it is frightening to find myself doing first one thing and then another to be a little bit more ready for the possibility of ????? What that means is i BELIEVE ......i don't WANT to believe.....Ray Gorham has made it an unbelievably realistic and every day "it COULD happen" not the science fiction i have imagined. Thank You! Looking forward to your next book....i am sure as with any good writer, less words will contain more content as each project is finished....keep going, you have our attention.

I'm not sure what the reviewer who gave 1 star and  a lot of arrogant advice wanted from this book, but I was more than satisfied. I read the book in a day. I could not put it down.  Like the majority of readers, I felt so drawn into the novel that I felt the fear, pain, cold, etc.. that the characters were experiencing.  I thought that in a quite possible scenario that would render most people hopeless, the main character, Kyle Tait was not that kind of person.  Nor was his wife.  They had abundant hope and determination in the face of a horrible situation. I felt every mile of Kyle's journey, and every uncertain day that Jennifer hoped for his return. I have read about the possibility for an EMP in a scientific context, but Mr. Gorham did a wonderful job of putting human faces to such a tragedy.  I liked the fact that there was hope and kindness throughout the novel, and that a man's love for his family pushed him beyond his known limits.  I  have already ordered the sequel, and I can't wait to read it.  Thank you Mr. Gorham, for educating us about a very real threat, while entertaining us with a fictional scenario of how the human race would handle it.  Loved it!!!

I really enjoyed this book.  I live about 10 miles north of Bush Intercontinental Airport where the opening scene of this novel begins.  I've also been to just about all the places in the book that the main character travels through, so I could really picture the landscapes in my mind as I read the book, which was an added bonus for me.  All that aside, however, I think this was an excellent effort by a new author and well worth the price of this book.  I liked it so much that I've downloaded the second installment in the series and I'm looking forward to reading more from this writer.  The characters were believable and well developed and the main character was truly an ordinary guy - not a silly Rambo fantasy badass.  The hero is heroic not for his survival prowess, but for his courage and tenacity as he struggles to survive and make it home against arduous odds. Good job, Mr. Gotham.
Exceptionally well written account of what happens to an ordinary, everyday family after an EMP attack. Excellent book.

Ray Gorham's "77 Days in September" was a very pleasant surprise. I write apocalyptic fiction myself, "The Dying Time: Impact" and "After The Dying Time" so I know first hand how hard it is to put together a good self-published book. Kyle Tait, the protagonist, isn't Rambo or an ex-Navy seal. He's just a good, decent man trying to get home to his loving family. His trails and tribulations making the long walk home--as well as the story of his waiting family and their struggles to survive--make this one of the very best books in this genre. Excellent writing and plotting. And well-edited. The story line was so strong and the characters so likeable that I immediately bought the second book in the series, "Daunting Days of Winter." My point is you can't go wrong reading Ray Gorham's books.

Congrats on the book.  Seems to be well received.  Comparisons to the "other" EMP book are a little misplaced as it is only logical that things would really start to deteriorate after Kyle got home - which you clearly understood with the reference to the increased break-ins as Kyle is speaking to his neighbor.  So the other EMP book is telling a different story - longer term deprivation, politics, etc...  Perfect stage for your book 2 to delve into the starvation, wild dogs,  disease,  gangs and other unpleasantries that would come soon after the first story ends. And yeah....anyone who thinks our enemies aren't all over this and that this is pure fantasy is sorely mistaken.

I found the task facing Kyle after The Event to be the most  daunting I could possibly imagine, and as an experienced survivalist and reader of post-apocalypse fiction, I can imagine quite a lot.  I won't give any spoilers here, but I only had two dislikes in the whole story, and neither had anything to do with the writing.  They were minor events that revealed an attitude toward physical life or death conflict that ... well, indicated a willingness to cave in to fear too readily.  But otherwise the writing is first-rate:  I could always visualize the scene, the weather, the feelings, the heartache, the fear, the triumph, the joy.  Definitely a worthwhile experience, and now I am starting on the sequel.  Congratulations, Mr. Gorham, a job well done.

Kyle Tait a Montana power company employee on loan to to a Huston.TX power comany after a hurricane. Nothing unusual about that until the power goes out and his plane crashes on take off. But when no emergence responders come something has happen beyond his plane going down. Your imagination is put to work what would happen if everything that required electricity failed? What panic and mayham would we see? This is a picture what could happen in a very descriptive way and one mans struggle to reach his wife and 3 children 1500 miles away. Does he make it and what will it take? Put your imagination to work how woulf you survive without electricity? Could some terrorist bring America to its knees like this? I enjoyed this novel hope you do too.

This is one of my favorite books. Ray Gorham paints a very realistic image of survival in an "end of the world as we know it" scenario in the book 77 Days in September. I was gripped from the very beginning, and didn't put the book down until I finished it. The book walks the reader through an America that is not altogether different than what we are seeing today, and illustrates some very thought provoking situations that force you to question your ability to survive in a world without the traditional luxuries we all take for granted like security and unending food supplies. I encourage anyone who is interested in "end of the world as we know it" matters to read this book. You won't be disappointed.

The book was enjoyable. Definitely worth the price. All people seem to have their own ideas on apocalyptic events. Which inevitably leads to criticisms. I think the author deserves the latitude in fiction up to a point. There were some inconsistencies but it was a very good book. My one strong dislike was the author inserting personal political views for the reader to swallow, there were only a few but why sarcastically criticize the government, upset half of your readers when you could have simply made the case that any government would be totally overwhelmed by the scale of even a small EMP event. Hope you write more books.

ONe of the most frightening books I have ever read. Its EASY to imagine this type of scenario actually happening. WHAT would happen to America if it did? This is SO REAL that it should scare everyone. The cyber attacks that are occuring on almost a daily basis now are minimal compared to the devestation that this type of attack would inflict, yet our Government has done NOTHING to inform the American people of this type of danger. And with Russia running wild along with other Communist and Arab countries becoming Nuclear Ready, wow, we DO need to take some action to try and get things under control. I'm really looking forward to reading the next book in the series.
Kept me on the edge of my seat for hours. Will purchase the next book in line ASAP..!

I've read several books in this genre, and really enjoyed this one. it was an overall good story, while not skimming to lightly over the realities of what life might be like if one were unprepared in a situation like this, or even if you were. Overall good storytelling, & I enjoyed the way the author went back and forth between home and traveler, giving us a picture of what happened on a day to day basis. I especially appreciated the fact that there was no need to add excessive blood, gore, or language. My only complaint would be that I would have enjoyed the book being longer with even more detail of day to day life.

I though this was a very well-written book. The scenario, though far-fetched, is possible and even though I have given some thought to the possibility of having to live a prepper lifestyle, there are aspects within the book that I had not thought of. The story was believable, the characters realistic and the plot held my interest and moved quickly enough to keep me reading. I reserve five-star ratings for books I would read a second or third time, and while I probably won't read this book again, I will keep the links you provided at end of the book and maybe do some further research on the subject of preparedness.

Cleverly written to keep the reader engrossed in the tale.  Kyle represents Mr Everybody with faults and a basic 'good' streak that surfaces when times get tough and adversity could easily deter him from getting home.  Jennifer, the wife and mother, holds the family together never giving up hope that her husband will return someday.  The movement back and forth from Kyle to Jennifer is seamless and keeps the readers attention... not an easy task.  Written with a descriptive, lyrical style that is easy to read but difficult to put down.  I highly recommend this new author and look forward to future works.

This book ranks among the best I've ever read, and I've read thousands of books!  It is tightly written, the plot moves along in a believable interesting way, and the characters are extremely likeable.  The situation that the narrative revolves around is one that is on everyone's mind in this day and age - what happens when all electricity is taken out.  What happens to the airplanes in the air, to cars on the road, to people far from home with no way to get there, to television, radio, power stations and so forth.  I loved this book!  It left me breathless, something few books have ever done.

I have read a lot of books - and this is my new favorite.  I breezed through this book in two days and couldn't hardly put it down in that period of time.  The writing style is excellent - and the author does not "over-develop" characters, which is a pet peeve of mine (i.e. Dean Koontz).  There is a steady stream of information and a sense of progress and suspense as the story unfolds.  I have already recommended this book to at least a half dozen people - and that was before I even finished it.  Great job, Ray.

This isn't as bad as some stories in the genre, but that's not saying much. The characters are one-dimensional (good hero, evil sheriff, lonely widow, kindly neighbor, etc.). The writer has a decent vocabulary, an idea of where he wants to go with his story, but it's still awfully boring. His understanding of women and women's thoughts/actions/motivations is nil, his hero is tedious and repetitive, his travails are predictable, and by the time I got to the middle of the book, I could barely get through to the end. I confess: I skimmed the last 100 pages because I was so over it.

Poorly written. Stilted conversations. (Do you use the name of the person you are conversing with every time you open your mouth? "John, why did the plane crash?" "John, have some coffee.") Illogical and ultimately boring action. Why doesn't he just ride a bike? Why walk!?  Sigh! Never, never pick a book based on the 5 star reviews. ALWAYS read the 1 star reviews!

It was very interesting to imagine how life would suddenly change if we lost all power. my family and I are completely unprepared. the story was pretty engaging. I had no idea where the story would go and was freaking out at each new person, expecting them to do something horrible. I was surprised by how many good people there were. the feelings behind story itself felt a bit mechanical to me, and I had a difficult time connecting emotionally. but then I real a lot of romance novels with flowing and eloquent descriptions. this book was very straight forward.

I purchased this book because of the reviews. I had to force myself to keep reading it. I don't know where to begin, the writing is sophomoric, the theory that this could actually happen isn't substantiated and the there is no common sense in the plot.  Don't buy it.  Seriously, it's awful.

This is a gripping, realistic story.  The author has done some in-depth research on this type of attack.  I wish someone in our government would take as hard a look at the potential for a major catastrophe as Gorham has.  The characters are well developed and you really care about what happens to them. I read some of the comments about the characters being a little too "good", but thankfully there are still people with the kind of values that the main couple exhibit.  This guy is good.  I look forward to another book from him.

Actually i was thrilled to finally read a book that had an obvious conclusion...then i learned that there is a book 2, however the story in book one stands alone, and while reminisent of a few other books on the subject, took me in a new direction, after the main character rescues his fellow passenger and stays with him a short while. His adventures walking home from Tx. To Montana are interesting, exciting, but not above or beyond most books with similar scenearios. All in all a good read, and worth the time, but not outstanding.

I have always liked to read books that propose 'what if' themes....77 Days in September...in this day and age this is totally possible and really started me thinking about how dependent we all are on computers, cellphones and electricity, in general. I loved how it was written and the characters that were introduced, but by the end of the book, I was disappointed only because I wanted to keep reading to hear how the story continued! Good job, I so wanted more and that is the sign of a great writer...when the reader wants more!!!

It was a good read. Read it straight through.  Provided some moral and ethical thought. So much so that I looked to see if Mr. Gorham had written anything else and to my surprise and delight I discovered the Daunting Days of Winter, The Kyle Tait Series Volume 2 .  Only negative is that I can't purchase an actual book as I like to share.  I don't have a kindle but discovered that I could purchase it on my 'other' digital e-reader. After all if we do get hit with an EMP what good will all these digital books be.  Keep'em coming!

In so many post-apocalyptic books, society instantly crumbles and good people quickly turn to violence and killing.  Instead of glamorizing or justifying murder, I like how this book focuses on the importance of family and how much Kyle loves his wife.  He just wants to get back to her, but he isn't recklessly killing everyone in his path, and he meets many good people along the way.  Stories like this restore my faith in humanity.  There's plenty of action and adventure, but tender emotion and family moments too.  Great story!

This subject is one that I often read, enjoy, and am most concerned about both for myself as well as for our country.  Far to many books are written without adequate research or even thinking the plot and possibilities through to a reasonable conclusion, this is not one of those books.  I really enjoyed the plot, the content, and the pace.  This book for me was written well enough that I felt that I could almost see the characters faces as they experienced the abrupt change in th  direction if their lives.  Enjoy the book.

A definitely plausible plot based on a real terrorist threat. I'm not sure whether a small weapon would cause quite such a comprehensive effect but it's possible. (roll on fibre optic communications. ). The story of travel under such conditions is plausible too, and realistic. The tale moves smoothly and steadily and I never felt like stopping reading. I strongly recommend this book and hope the author produces more such works. There needs to be work to find ways of shielding the technology on which we all depend so much.

The number one reason this book is getting five stars from me is the important issue it addresses.  As a country, we are too reliant on technology, and have made ourselves vulnerable to an EMP attack.  This book explores what might happen were an attack to occur.  Reason number two for the five stars is it doesn't have the violent, sexually graphic, explicit language that a lot of survival books have and I really appreciate that.  Be warned, there are still some gritty things that happen, this is not a book for kids.

Generally OK. Interesting to hear about the aftereffects of an EMP attack, but the story of the journey wore a bit thin, and filler parts of the two main character's stories was a little boring. There were areas of misspelling (possessives I believe) that a proofreader would have easily caught, and an editor could have tightened up the story. I'm being a bit hard on the author, and it's not something I felt I couldn't plow through (it's readable enough), but a series like Hugh Howey's Wool was much more engaging.

I read a similar story a few years ago and looked for another apocalyptic story to read and thought I would try this one. With a two year old, it is hard for me to get some good reading time in so I bring them to the gym with me to read while doing cardio. This story keeps me engrossed and 90 min is over before I know it. I enjoy the story so much that I have to force myself not to pick it up during the day when I am off work and should be doing laundry. Look forward to future books from this author.

Using the premise of an EMP(electro-magnetic pulse) wiping out all the electronics in the country, sending life back 150 years, the author uses the story of one family to exemplify the struggle for survival, not only physically, but emotionally and morally. As a determined father walks over 1000 miles to get home, his wife and children learn to adapt to new realities. Hard to put down. The truly frightening notion is that this could happen. It makes the reader think about the choices they would make.

Bummer. When I saw all the five-star reviews I thought I was in for a quality apocalypse story. The concept was sound, massive infrastructure damage with relatively limited casualties, something different from the nuclear holocaust or fatal virus type stories. Unfortunately the idea was lost in a mess of poor character development, slopping narative and unbelievable dialogue. Also, there's only 30 days in September. Barely managed to finish this one, skipped paragraphs at a time to minimise the pain.
The book chapters are much like a train of box cars, each with its own content and each independent of the other.  Neat action, a quick read, but not a great book!
Author really needs a remedial grounding in modern electronics. EMP just don't work this way. If it did, our civilization would fail at every major solar flare.

The adventures of Kyle's trip home show just how the human lifestyle changes.  The many that turned into an animal state of crime or criminals.  This mixed along with the many acts of kindness shows what we could degrade into.  The way he tells it opens so many thoughts of how we need to prepare for in the future.  It is obvious that the Government will not be of any help and we need to be able to be on our own for extended periods of time. We need to start getting ready.  Excellent read.

I READ THE SAMPLE ON MY KINDLE, I ORDERED THE BOOK ON MY KINDLE FROM AMAZON YESTERDAY. THIS IS THE SECOND EMP BOOK I HAVE READ.  I FINISHED IT A 4:30 A.M. THIS MORNING.  YES I LIKED IT. IT WAS MORE ABOUT THE PERSONAL SIDE OF ONE MAN'S EXPERIENCE IN TRYING TO GET HOME TO HIS FAMILY AND HIS INTERACTION WITH THOSE HE MET ALONG THE WAY DURING THE BREAKDOWN OF SOCIETY IN THE AFTER MATH OF AN EMP.  WORTH THE READ.

Read the entire book in two sittings, besides being a great story I am afraid it could very possibly be a prophetic look at America's future. Ironically, after finishing the book saw an interview with a former head of the C.I.A. And he said this (an EMP attack somewhere over America) was what kept him awake at nights. I would encourage us all to Pray, Pray and then Pray some more for God's continued Divine Protection of America. Look forward to reading the second book in this series.

There are many books like this one available, but they tend to jump around a lot.  This focuses on one person who understands what happened and is trying to get home to his family.  The premise of the book is totally accurate, and contrary to popular belief, could actually happen.  Everyone should be aware of this possibility and not shrug it off as a 'conspiracy theory' put forth by a 'bunch of preppers'.  Just read the book and open your mind to the possibility and repercussions.

An EMP blast shatters the 21st century world in America, leaving a man alone. This is his story of traveling back to his family. While he journeys across a shattered landscape this book also chronicles his family's difficulties at home waiting for his return. While this a SHTF book, it is more than that, it shows what a person can do, what hardships might be endured for love and family. This book is well written and I thank the author for getting a good editor, very few errors.

Great book with very believable events that kept me turning the pages until I was finished.  I don't often read a book without  stop but this was one that had me.  It seemed like the author ran out of steam in the final couple of chapters and wanted to get the book finished and rushed everything from the Montana state line on out.  Every other aspect of the book was very well developed and made sense.

My husband ordered this book on my kindle for me. I really enjoyed the story and it made me think about what we would do if this actually happened. I read a book when I was in high school similar to this. It was Alas Babylon. It has always been one of my favorite books and I will now add this book to my book favorites. I am reading the sequel to this book  and it is as good if not better then the first book. I am looking forward to reading more Ray Gorham's books in the future.

Entertaining as well as thought provoking.  Familiar with the EMP threat, and know our government isn't paying attention AT ALL.  Are you prepared?  Society calls "preppers" crazy now. When the ballon goes up, they'll be the only ones with a real chance to survive and even thrive.  As I close, I have to mention that my name is also Kyle, and I'd have stayed with Rose for a few more days. LOL. Read the book and you'll understand what this means. Really enjoyed the book.

77 Days In September was a mildly entertaining, sanitized version of what would be a catastrophic, life-changing event for all of us.  Mr. Gorham lightly touched on some of the ramifications of an EMP event ----an electromagnetic pulse caused by the detonation of a nuclear device in the atmosphere.  If the power grid of the United States and all that it supports were destroyed, our life support system would suddenly stop.  The main character in this story is stranded in Texas and needs to make it back to Montana, where his wife and children live. The characters in the story are upset and inconvenienced, but the reader never gets a true sense of a life-threatening desperation.  With all transportation, communication devices, and all electrical systems fried, there would be no food deliveries, no medical supplies, no running water, cars would not run, and planes would not fly.  Within weeks, if not days, millions of people would find themselves hungry, thirsty, and especially in cities, with no way of alleviating these basic needs.  Mr. Gorham lightly touched on this, then promptly forgot there are about 300 million people in the United States, about 90 million of them in the Western U.S. where our main character is traveling, for the most part alone, in a scenario reminiscent of The Road.  For a far more realistic account of an EMP event read One Second After by William Forstchen.
